svg.aria-label: Architecture of regimes: web-open versus agentic-closed
svg.text: Architecture of regimes: web-open vs agentic-closed
Interpretive Governance (layer 1) governs surfaces and claim legitimacy; Constraintive Governance (layer 2) governs runtime only when execution is controlled.
Regime A — web-open
Regime B — agentic-closed
Human cognition ≠ LLM calculation; no internal intention or lived memory; governance must be external.
Stabilizes conceptual ground; non-operational.
Layer 1 — Interpretive Governance (surfaces only)
Canonical surfaces, explicit negations, entity graphs, clarification indexes.
Claim typing: observed / derived / inferred / unknown.
Legitimate non-response when interpretive conditions are missing.
No control over runtime parameters, orchestration, validation, or abstention enforcement.
Therefore: layer 2 is inapplicable.
Layer 1 — Interpretive Governance (surfaces + claim legitimacy)
Same interpretive constraints as web-open (surfaces + typed claims).
Used inside the system to govern what may be asserted and what must remain unknown.
Remains central; does not become a runtime mechanism.
Layer 2 — Constraintive Governance (runtime substrate)
Bounded retrieval (allowlist), fixed inference parameters, schema validation, enforced abstention.
Controls execution conditions: what may be retrieved, computed, emitted, retried, or refused.
Enables reliable enforcement of layer 1 constraints at runtime.
Pipeline: typed request → bounded retrieval → LLM call (fixed config) → schema validation → accept / abstain
Key boundary: web-open governs surfaces only; agentic-closed adds runtime constraint enforcement as a separate layer.
